texts.definition: The goal to move and perform actions while remaining undetected.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal to move and perform actions while remaining undetected.</style>

Sometimes favorable conditions in a game can be achieved by not having one's actions noticed by other players. When this is the case, players have <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals that make  them to plan actions that minimize the risks of being noticed while still completing the required actions. Naturally, this can also be made into explicit design goals so that games are lost or penalties received for failing to be stealthy.

Some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Children's%20Games">Childrens' Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Burken">Burken</link></style>, are based on one person trying to find the other players while at the same time trying to guard an area that is a safe zone for the other players. If the other players, by a combination of <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> and running, make it to the safe zone they are home free and do not have to be the player guarding the safe zone in the next game.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> or third-person action games replace combat challenges with <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> challenges, or let players choose which way to play. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metal%20Gear%20Solid%20series">Metal Gear Solid</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thief%20series">Thief series</link></style> are examples of games which emphasis <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> gameplay while the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> have them as options for players.

<style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> is a compound goal pattern most often based on combining <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>. While these two patterns are necessary for <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> to appear, other patterns often provide the motivation for the traversal. <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> of a guarded item, making a <style="Link"><link="deliver">Delivery</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> somebody that others are <style="Link"><link="guard">Guarding</link></style>, achieving <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, covertly gaining knowledge from others' <style="Link"><link="information-passing">Information Passing</link></style>, or avoiding or hiding in <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style> are all examples of such motivations. Other patterns can create <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> by encouraging the combination of <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals. <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> explicitly provide ways <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> can be achieved and thereby motivate the goal to be adopted. Using <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> for motion detectors or other sensors can give players concrete gameplay areas to avoid (especially if these are visualized, e.g. as laser beams). <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> can indirectly create <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals since they can give players <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals to players already having <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals. Combining <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> and <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals make players engage in <style="Link"><link="scouting">Scouting</link></style>. Designing <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goal consist not only of choosing between the different design options of these patterns, but also determining what player actions can reveal the players and what the <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> are between the various <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> relations for each action in a given context.

While <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> is typically assumed to be related to keeping <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> undetected, games which use <style="Link"><link="physical-navigation">Physical Navigation</link></style> can instead make the <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> relate to the players themselves. Games which want to differentiate between parts where <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> is focused upon and other parts can do this through having other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> (potentially with <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals) have <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style> related to this.

The difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals can be modulated by many different types of patterns. <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style>, which is a necessity for <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> due to enabling <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals, can also modify the difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals by how common and how good the <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style> are. <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> are in many cases taken for granted as possible actions for <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals, so removing these can make them significantly more difficult. Similarly, succeeding with <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> often requires <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style> activities but these are not always intentionally supported; doing so can make <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals easier to achieve. <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals do actually not need <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, but providing such with <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals making the <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals more difficult. <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> can make them more difficult since players may more easily be discovered while <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> can make them easier by providing options (besides making them possible to begin with). <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> about the gameplay area to be traversed is nearly always beneficial for <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals, so letting players have this or have the possibility to have this can also ease the challenge. Giving players <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals combined with <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals increases the chances of failure and thereby provide more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>.

In games which uses technologies to achieve <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-player-proximity">Player-Player Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style> can allow players to use <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> by moving out of the coverage areas of those technologies.

<style="Link"><link="sanctioned-cheating">Sanctioned Cheating</link></style> provides a different type of <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals to players in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>: they can try to perform various <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> without other players noticing these.

<style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals can sometimes be difficult to succeed because it can be difficult to judge how noticeable one's <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> is. <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, e.g. the "visibility" gem in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thief%20series">Thief series</link></style>, can be added to a game to provide this information to players to increase their situational awareness. Games in which players need to themselves be stealthy, i.e. through the use of <style="Link"><link="physical-navigation">Physical Navigation</link></style> or at least physical <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, avoids this.

<style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> is the <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goal</link></style> of trying to <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> one's location while having to do some <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>. This typically creates <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> since being discovered bring clear <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. These types of goals may require players to pace themselves as quick or effective <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> may have too high risks, and sometimes any action or <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> may cause the goal to fail. <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> can thus create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations and sometimes require players to perform <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No-Op">No-Op</link></style> actions if these are at all possible. For <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, performing the actions required to complete <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals are likely to be <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>.

Many cases of <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> rely on opponents having <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style>, making <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> and these goals <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>. Other cases rely on players wanting to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> to commit <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style>. Both types of cases can be used as the basis for <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> but also for creating <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> goals if players need to perform actions that would break their - possibly only perceived - <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> if they were observed. If these <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals are <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> game items only for monetary gains while wanting to appear an honest citizen, this is an example of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> possibility.

The slow tempo and possible pauses in completing <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> goals give players a chance to make use of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, e.g. the locations of <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, to do <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> although this often needs to be modified by <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> due to unplanned situation, e.g. noticing <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals. Both these aspects of planning make <style="CurrentLink">Stealth</style> provide <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, and in many cases these depend on how perception works in the games which often makes <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> important.

<style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="information-passing">Information Passing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-player-proximity">Player-Player Proximity</link></style>
